entry.title: Combined summary - An overview of the cluster mempool proposal
entry.summary:
The text explores the intricacies of transaction management in networked systems, with a focus on the mempool's transaction eviction and re-entry. It critiques current replacement mechanisms and debates whether to aim for an optimal solution or to make incremental improvements. A proposed alternative involves temporarily exceeding cluster limits followed by linearization and pruning.
There is a dialogue about reformulating 'carveout' rules for transactions that bypass standard mempool restrictions, such as those used by the Lightning Network (LN), considering factors like transaction size and output expenditures. The complexity of ensuring compatibility with the cluster mempool necessitates continued research.
A sibling eviction policy is discussed as an alternative to the CPFP carveout rule, allowing some transactions to evict other transactions that share the same unconfirmed parent. This policy's economic and usability impacts are explored, alongside its potential benefits and added complexity.
The concept of incentive-compatibility in fee rates is also examined, suggesting that fees at the top of the mempool should be weighted more heavily. The possibility of discounting mechanisms could innovate mempool dynamics and fee management, though these ideas remain theoretical.
Challenges in comparing different mempool states are addressed, emphasizing the need for a framework to compare profitability based on fee rates and transaction volumes. Replace-By-Fee (RBF) rules and their implications are analyzed, particularly when smaller, higher-fee transactions aim to replace larger transactions with lower fees.
A new design for the Bitcoin Core mempool suggests policy changes to enforce cluster size limitations, replacing ancestor and descendant limits, and revising RBF rules. Incoming transactions must offer a "strictly better feerate diagram" to be accepted, potentially making the CPFP rule obsolete. This approach seeks to maintain a total ordering of transactions, align eviction and mining selection algorithms with miner incentives, and simplify the organization of transactions for improved efficiency.
The proposal emphasizes strict adherence to cluster sizes without exceptions. It considers redefining policy frameworks to support specific transaction topologies within cluster size constraints. The design promises better mining transaction selection and eviction processes through descending feerate order iterations, eliminating the need for monitoring ancestor and descendant counts, which could reduce CPU overhead.
For further details and technical explanations, one can refer to the original write-up by @sipa and review the initial draft implementation, noting that continuous enhancements and parameter adjustments are expected after further analysis and benchmarking.
